As it is an emotional issue, there has been a lot of angst on behalf of both custodial and noncustodial parents in my electorate of Gilmore, and it has been apparent for a long time that changes had to be made. Some of these have been addressed by this government, as the previous Labor government thought it was all too hard. Bear that in mind. I can give members of the Main Committee a quick example of why the current legislation is not working. However, I am sure they all have plenty of their own cases where parents, and in particular children, are facing unnecessary extra financial and emotional burdens because of the unworkable nature of the current system. In Gilmore we have a number of non-custodial parents. It is a fact that they are mostly fathers, though this should not become an issue of gender because that serves only to cloud further a very muddy debate. But there are many noncustodial parents who are struggling to support two families under the current system.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Gash (Gilmore) (12.25 P.m.)
theText: As a member of the child support subcommittee I riseWednesday, 1 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2323 We have grown men who have been forced to return home to the support of their parents in order to be able to continue to meet child support payments. We have non-custodial parents who are better off on welfare because they cannot meet the obligations set down by the Child Support Agency. In one particular case in Gilmore there is a gentleman who has had to resort to living in a tent in order to continue paying for the upkeep of his children, who live with their mother, even though he never sees them and rarely has other contact. By the same token, the need for strong child support laws and their enforcement is undeniable. I have cases of custodial parents who cannot afford to clothe their children, while the non-custodial parent is living comfortably but refuses to pay their share in the raising of their children, which is still a joint responsibility of parents. And we have nori-custodial parents who, far from being forced to apply for income support, do so in order to avoid paying their share of child support for their children. It is a system which lays as much guilt on children as it does on each parent. Having gone through it myself, I can honestly say that no party is ever free from blame in the fallout from divorce. However, there are some things which can be done to make it easier for children and for their parents to fulfil their obligations and responsibilities to each other and their former families. By introducing changes to the child support scheme this government has made steps, albeit small steps, in the right direction. For example, removing the obligation of the Child Support Agency to become involved has been a vital issue. There are cases in my electorate of Gilmore, as there would be throughout Australia, where the parents have come to a mutually agreeable arrangement on the issue of child support, yet the agency has determined a different figure and demands to be involved. This demand had the support of the original legislation and it came with an ultimatum from the Department of Social Security that unless the Child Support Agency's agreement was met, the custodial parent would lose their income support. Where is the logic in that? Removing the Child Support Agency from all agreements, unless they are required to become involved, is a major step in ensuring the best outcome for both parents and, subsequently but more importantly, for the children. However the Child Support Agency should not be made out to be the big bad ogre in all of this, for the support I and my staff have received from agency officers has been tremendous. We have come to an arrangement whereby, every month, agency staff travel from their base in Wollongong to my electorate office in Nowra to hold private interviews with parents who have concerns over child support agreements. The feedback I am getting so far has been very positive. We have managed to resolve most cases just by arranging face-to-face meetings between parties and the agency. These interviews will continue for as long as necessary, even following the positive changes introduced by this government. While the House is well aware of the changes which we introduced, I would like to quickly refer to the specific reforms which have made the most difference to the lives of many people in my Gilmore electorate. The change to the family payment income test for payers with second families will increase assistance for non-custodial parents with second families. This measure sees non-custodial parents with second families able to claim 50 per cent of any child support they pay as a deduction from the household income which is used for determining the family's entitlement to family payment and child-care assistance. This measure is fair to all 2324 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 April 1998 parties as it ensures that custodial parents do not lose access to financial support for their children and non-custodial parents receive extra support for their second families. Another measure was to introduce a minimum child support liability measure for all players, including those on income support at $260 per year or $5 per week, which, in the past legislation, was not introduced. This will fulfil the recommendation-of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues which looked into child support-that there should be minimum payment and the principle that some contribution towards the cost of raising a child is an obligation of all parents, even those who do not have the day-to-day demands of the child as part of their routines and their budgets. One of the major reforms introduced by this government is one which I, as a former representative of the New South Wales Domestic Violence Advisory Council, totally support and that is to ensure consistency in the treatment of family violence cases. Before1 January this year, there was no mechanism to assist parents at risk of family violence to commence or continue collecting child support from their violent spouse. Imagine for a moment that you are at risk from a violent partner. Imagine the pain, humiliation and fear which is part of your everyday family life. When you finally gather the courage to make the move away from this intolerable and unacceptable position, you find yourself in the further untenable, unenviable situation of having to face your-partner for funding for the upkeep of your children. This is a totally humiliating experience, to say the least, and it is certainly one which many custodial parents choose not to go through and, therefore, they are left without the financial support for the upkeep of their children which is their right under the law. Now they have the support of the agency case managers to go through such demanding obstacles and they can continue with their lives with as few financial difficulties as possible. That is a move which has been a long time coming and one which I certainly applaud. However, as I stated at the outset, these changes are just three of the 18 introduced by this government and they are just the tip of the iceberg in terms of what is required for greater support and equality in the child support scheme for all parents and their children. I am constantly reminded by letters and phone calls from constituents of Gilmore that the changes have not yet gone far enough. The fact that this government has recognised the need for change and done something about it is always commended by my residents who are affected by child support or who know of someone who is, whether it be their son who they are continuing to support as he faces financial difficulties or their daughter who cannot find enough money to feed and clothe herself and her children. But-and there is always a 'but' at the end of their sentences-more needs to be done. This is something that we have recognised, with further reforms being debated in the subcommittee on child support. We have presented submissions to the relevant ministers, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) and the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), outlining details of what must be done, and yes, they are listening. These changes include the need to reassess the amount of child support which is paid by a non-custodial parent to their former partner. At present, the means test for such arrangements is unfair and there are a number of proposals for reforming this issue, particularly in relation to overtime pay and changes in income following the time after the marriage is dissolved. Why is it that non-custodial parents who spend their time doing overtime to better provide for their second families must be forced to pay some of that money to the first family, when it was not something that they had access to at the time of their marriage? Who pays when Wednesday, 1 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2325 the child is with the non-custodial parent for a length of time? This alone often causes financial strain and when added to the cost of the visit-sometimes to another state and over which noncustodial parents have no control-the burden is and can be enormous. This is one of the major 'buts' which my constituents bring to me and it is one which needs to be addressed. There is scope for addressing it in the next round of reforms which this government will introduce. The changes which came into effect on 1 January were the second stage of a three-stage process which has been evolving over the two years that we have been in government. Understandably, in such an emotive issue, there must be a balance to achieve a fair outcome for all parties. To do so requires wide consultation with comm.unity groups and representative organisations, as well as with the agency itself, to determine the most appropriate changes to make and the most effective ways of implementing them. I welcome the chance to provide input to this debate from the people of Gilmore, and I will continue to work with the child support subcommittee for a fairer outcome for all parents and, more importantly, for their children. . to enter this debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998. It is a very difficult time in the lives of so many people when they and their children are unfortunate enough to experience separation or divorce. No-one would argue with the fact that the child support scheme, as it stands, desperately needs overhauling. It is an unfair and inadequate system of assessing and collecting support for children whose parents are separated and/or divorced. The children of the nation ought to be the responsibility of all citizens, but primarily they are the responsibility of both parents. When, through no fault on the part of the children, the parents' relationship breaks down, the children should not be made the pawns. In an ideal world, both parents should continue to support the children financially, emotionally and in providing role models, but in most cases separation and divorce is not an amicable arrangement. The usual arrangement, depending on the age of the child or on the ages of the children, is that one parent is given custody, with the other being given access. However, in too many instances the custodial parent uses child support as a bargaining tool. We need to establish a fair and just procedure for collecting child support that is based on the needs of the child or children and on the capacity of both parents to pay. It seems so simple, but in reality it is far from that. The matter of child support affects so many of our citizens and causes much anger, angst, heartache and suffering. Something like 40 per cent of marriages in this nation end up in divorce, many involving children. A number of constituents have come to me for help with a wide range of personal examples that point to the inadequacies of the child support scheme. There is no doubt that some custodial parents understate their income. Creative accounting for some self-employed persons can vary the income received, albeit legally, by conceding the income in several ways, not the least of which is by family trusts. On the other hand, there are many examples of a custodial parent denying access to the other parent whether or not child support is paid in that instance. Contributions should be assessed on net income, not on gross income, and overtime should not come into the equation. Another area of concern raised by a constituent recently is losses from investment properties that should be considered in the assessment of child support liability. If the non-custodial
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Zammit (Lowe) (12.35 P.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity2326 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 April 1998 parent were to realise a capital gain from selling the same property, the agency would include profits realised in the assessment. It is grossly unfair. Other aspects which require addressing include the question of the formula, which I believe is too rigid. Individual assessments should be carried out which look at the needs of the child and the capacity of parents to pay. There needs to be a link between maintenance and support payments and access. If the custodial parent denies access for no valid reason, that parent should have to show cause as to why the child support maintenance payment should not be terminated. We owe it to the thousands who are affected by child support to provide real change which removes the biases and offers genuine and long-lasting solutions which are fair and just. I hasten to add that I am not being critical of the agency which collects child support. They are doing the best they can with a complex and emotionally charged issue. However, there is no doubt that the agency can increase its vigilance and diligence in investigating individual cases. As is the case with other underresourced government departments, there is no doubt that the agency is overworked and understaffed. The system needs overhauling in order to give equity and fairness to the parties concerned and, primarily, to safeguard the welfare of the children. The way child support operates at the moment pushes people into finding ways and means of avoiding the payment. If the system is not fair and not seen to be fair, why bother working? It is not flexible enough, in my view, to accommodate changes which are occurring in many cases within a short period of time in the working life of the parties involved. Some of the people who have come to see me on the matter of child support are almost suicidal and in some cases they are undergoing psychiatric counselling because the system is stacked against them. How does all this impact on the children? Very negatively, I would suggest. The bill before the House underscores the fundamental principle that parents are primarily responsible for the financial support of their children, and the government, through these measures, would not intrude unnecessarily into people's lives. I support some of the changes which have been proposed to the child support scheme which will address some of the concerns expressed by my constituents, such as the inclusion of net rental property losses and exempt foreign income into taxable income for child support purposes. The exempt income amount will be increased by 10 per cent, recognising the cost of employment faced by payers. Payers with second families will now be able to claim 50 per cent of any child support paid as a deduction from the household income used for determining the family's entitlement to family payment and child-care assistance. The objectives of the scheme will be revised to recognise that both parents are responsible for the support of their children. Whilst many of these recommendations come into effect on 1 July 1998, regrettably some will have to wait until 1 July 1999. We must stop tinkering at the edges and provide real solutions by implementing the recommendations made by the joint select committee. The proposals need to take into account the level of disregard of the income for custodial parents, that is, the amount the custodial parent can earn before any reductions in the noncustodial parent's child support payments. The government is encouraging parents to escape from the clutches of the Child Support Agency and deal with child support matters themselves, Wednesday, 1 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2327 and that is a very important initiative. This is a very smart move, since estimates suggest that the money recovered by the agency is less than half the costs of administering the system. The review system needs overhauling, and the need for introducing a less costly system of appeals is absolutely vital. Not a great deal more can be said about this. This is only a start. It is a step in the right'direction and a lot more needs to be done. I would urge the government to move with haste in bringing these changes into effect so as to lessen the pain, suffering and anguish so many people feel at a particularly vulnerable period of their lives. conditional-support for the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998. I was here earlier when the member for Wills( Mr Kelvin Thomson) made a suggestion that the government was supporting the Labor Party's child support formula, et cetera, and he made this observation on the basis that we were only 'tinkering with the edges'. I suggest to you that the whole system is haemorrhaging. To suggest that we are fully supportive of it, quite frankly, is a nonsense. The problem, of course, is dollars and cents. It does cost a lot of money to deal with these issues and, unfortunately, given the position that we were left in, it is going to take some time to replenish the coffers to be able to give back to this the proper balance that is required. Having said that, the measures that are contained in this bill have been designed to introduce some flexibility into the child support scheme and reduce unnecessary bureaucratic intervention. As I said earlier, the measures certainly do not go far enough. They are just the first wave of reforms by this government-reforms that are becoming increasingly urgent, I might point out, as more families are drawn into the child support scheme at a tragically rapid rate. My support for these reforms, as I have stated at all levels of debate on this issue, is given on the condition that a second wave of reform will follow very close behind, bringing fairer and more workable solutions to the enormous inequities in the child support scheme that is currently operating. A level of the problems out there could be demonstrated recently with the 60 Minutes program on problems within the child support system. It was reported at that time that it was one of the largest volumes of mail that they have received for any program. It shows that there are a lot of people out there sharing these concerns. Since my election to the seat of Leichhardt in 1996, a significantly large and increasing number of constituent grievances received in my office have been associated with the child support scheme and the Child Support Agency. Problems relate to both the legislation governing child support and its administration. Grievances are received from both child support paying and child support receiving parents. What most constituents complain about is the manner in which the system is administered and the problems subsequently caused by the shortcomings of this administration. It is a fact that many child support paying parents are living from hand to mouth. For them, life is mere existence. The enormous problems and obstacles child support parents face need to be recognised. Recent statistics provided by the Child Support Agency reveal that there are 7,587 child support payers and 4,920 child support payees in my electorate of Leichhardt. So the child support scheme invades the everyday lives of many thousands of my constituents and their families. This bill will actively encourage parents to move away from the Child Support Agency into private collection agreements. This is designed to encourage parents to take greater
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Entsch (Leichhardt) (12.42 P.m.)
theText: I rise today to offer my conditional-and I stress2328 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 Apri11998 responsibility for their child support arrangements. It will remove the bureaucracy from the lives of the payers, many of whom have contacted me and said they were completely disgusted that after many years of faithfully meeting their child support liability, they suddenly found their wages had been garnisheed and their tax refunds seized without any prior warning. I should point out that you cannot entirely blame the bureaucracy for this. It is a very emotional issue. The first piece of advice that I give to anybody who comes into my office with a problem relating to these issues is that if they really want to get a fair and equitable solution, no matter how much they dislike their ex-partner they should sit down and talk to them. I advise that because anything that they can agree on is going to be infinitely better than anything that is going to be dictated to them by bureaucrats and by those who really do not have a real understanding of the situation. Unfortunately, there are very few who are able to do that, and as a consequence it is almost like a war zone out there. For the first time ever there will be a minimum liability, an annual liability of $260 which has been applied to reinforce the principle that parents of the child have a primary duty to maintain that child and to share the costs of supporting that child. It will also be collected from recipients of social security benefits or pensions, and that is a great initiative. Irrespective of the amount of money, it is one way at least of acknowledging that there is some responsibility there, whatever the circumstance. Under this bill the exempt income applicable to child support payers will be increased by 10 per cent to $9,907 for single payers and to $16,525 for payers caring for other children, plus additional amounts for each child for payers with natural or adopted children in their care. This bill also introduces some flexibility by taking into account the paying parent's legal duty to maintain a stepchild. Payers with second families will now be able to claim 50 per cent of the child support payments as a deduction from household income used to determine eligibility for family payment and child-care assistance. Payers with second families have long been the poor relation of the child support scheme. Their child support liability often leaves them almost destitute and forces them to leave work to go on the dole because of the unfairness of the payments demanded of them. An example brought to my office related to a constituent who had accrued a debt of $30,000. He was making payments directly to his ex-wife but the Child Support Agency had no details of these payments and his ex-wife denied receiving payments for child support. The Child Support Agency immediately garnisheed his wage and presented him with a bill for arrears of child support backdated to the date of his settlement in the Family Court. There were a number of reviews, the last one resulting in the advice that the review officer was unable to form a clear view as to what had happened in the past years. Therefore, the review officer declined to make any decision and my constituent's debt still stands. He is remarried now and he is currently taking home one-third of his wages: one-third goes to child support payments, one-third to tax and one-third is left over to cover his daily expenses. As a result, his wife works 12 to 14 hours a day to help cover expenses. To add further stress to the situation, he has not seen his children for over two years. 'you would agree that this situation is far from conducive to a secure and happy marriage. There is no possibility of this couple considering having a family of their own at this stage as they simply cannot afford it. This bill will enable' child support assessments to be calculated using the most current taxable income available to each parent. Assessments are currently calculated according to a Wednesday, 1 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2329 formula which uses taxable income from two years prior. Re-assessment based on income can only be requested where income drops by 15 per cent from that used for the initial assessment. Concern is frequently expressed about the accuracy of this assessment process. Measures contained in this bill should allow more accurate and timely assessment of the capacity of parents to pay child support. This bill will introduce significant reform in the area of objection and appeal rights. A range of decisions, which are now only reviewable by the Family Court, will be subject to an internal review mechanism. It is hoped that this will improve perceptions of fairness, equity and the accountability of the Child Support Agency. Many instances are brought to my attention by paying parents where they have waited sometimes for months to have a review completed, then they receive notice that the review decision has gone against them. To add insult to injury, they then learn a decision can only be reviewed in the Family Court. This is often a last straw with limited access to legal aid and income already stretched to the limit with child support payments. They have no possibility of affording legal representation so they just accept the decision. It is just another body blow. When I rose today I stressed that my support for the bill was conditional on further urgent reform to the child support scheme. The enormous distress and frustration suffered by parents when the system fails to work for them, and creates other difficulties as a result, does nothing for the betterment of the children involved and ultimately does a great disservice to the community in general. The child support paying parent has little relief under the current scheme. The fact is that these parents, too, need to set up a home, rebuild and stabilise their lives. The government must address ongoing reforms in the following areas. Most of my constituents agree that some other type of formula is needed to arrive at a reasonable amount payable for child supportA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesCommittee for today. Leave granted; debate adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 12.54 p.m.
